A review of innovative approaches to the planning, design and management of the 'sustainable city', with an emphasis on techniques which seek to maintain and/or improve air quality, water quality and biodiversity. Topics include principles of urban ecology and sustainable development, the ecological  'footprint' of the metropolis, water cycle management, urban design and transportation issues, urban forestry, parks systems and greenways, use of tools for assessment/evaluation. The course will be based on lectures, seminars and case studies.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SUSD0002","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SUSD0002 - Building Ecology and Life Cycle Thinking","description":"

This course introduces and applies a whole-of-life approach to built environment sustainability. It discusses the life cycle of built form from the availability and acquisition of natural resources and raw materials, through processing and manufacture to on-site construction and use, maintenance and refurbishment, and eventual demolition and reuse/recycling or disposal. The environmental impacts at each stage of the life cycle are considered, such as initial and recurrent embodied energy, wastes generated and their management, and ways in which design may minimise or eliminate such impacts.

contentlets.keywords: sustainable development,sustainability,building materials,life cycle assessment,rating tools,construction sector
contentlets.description: This course introduces and applies a whole-of-life approach to built environment sustainability. It discusses the life cycle of built form from the availability and acquisition of natural resources and raw materials, through processing and manufacture to on-site construction and use, maintenance and refurbishment, and eventual demolition and reuse/recycling or disposal. The environmental impacts at each stage of the life cycle are considered, such as initial and recurrent embodied energy, wastes generated and their management, and ways in which design may minimise or eliminate such impacts.
contentlets.title: Building Ecology and Life Cycle Thinking

This course provides an overview of energy related issues in the built environment such as, demand and supply, technologies and infrastructure, greenhouse gas/ carbon emissions, and energy related interactions with other aspects of sustainable development. Various aspects of energy efficient cities, precinct and buildings are explored. In addition, tools for assessing energy performance of the built environment are also introduced. The course further discusses related policies, planning, design, management and technological strategies applied at different scales and stages in the built environment, drawing on the best practice 'real world' case studies.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SUSD0004","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SUSD0004 - Sustainability and Habitability","description":"

This course provides an overview of the complex interrelationships between human beings and the built environment which underpin habitability (liveability, quality of life) as a dimension of sustainability. Frameworks to describe, explain and interpret these human / built environment relations and interactions at different scales are introduced and applied, drawing on current research. The course discusses the potential for policy, planning, design and management of the built environment to influence habitability across the fundamental human dimensions of health and wellbeing; safety and security; comfort and amenity; and access, equity and community engagement. The course is structured around lectures, readings and class seminars; assessment is based on both individual and group work.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"04b1fae3db8e9410eb6b147a3a96192f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2: Team-based POE","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Groups will present their work using PowerPoint or similar for discussion and feedback during the third tutorial (Week 10). Teams must also provide written and appropriately illustrated POE reports of approx. 5000 words (i.e. about 1000 words plus illustrations supplied by each team member). They are to be submitted as Turnitin assignments via Moodle.

Presentation 10%
Report 30%

The group grade is adjusted through a team evaluation process, where students rate their own and other team members' contributions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"84b1fae3db8e9410eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"84b1fae3db8e9410eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8cb1fae3db8e9410eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2cfc32efdb8e9410eb6b147a3a96194e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"ASSIGNMENT 1c : Investigation of a place - Final Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be assigned to POE teams of five students, with cross-disciplinary representation as the main selection criterion. Each team will be responsible for
• choosing its own preferred building for the POE;
• initiating contact with the relevant building owner/manager; and
• arranging site access.
This should be done as early as possible, as there may be delays outside the team’s control. Several UNSW buildings may also be available for study, based on the premise that universities can effectively teach and demonstrate the theory and practice of sustainability through taking action to understand and reduce the unsustainable impacts of their own activities. However, students should not rely on UNSW buildings being available.

The report is given a group mark; each group will be assessed on the insight, relevance and applicability of their findings and the clarity and professionalism of their report. Team members will also be asked to rate their own and each other’s contribution to the team effort (peer review). This peer review variable will be averaged, and multiplied against the group mark to provide individual marks for each team member. The report should be referenced where required, and the format should follow the general structure of a professional consultant’s report. De-identified examples are available on Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"80b1fae3db8e9410eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"84b1fae3db8e9410eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8cb1fae3db8e9410eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8cb1fae3db8e9410eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4dacf2afdb8e9410eb6b147a3a96198f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1a: Investigation of a place - Project proposal (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"0","description":"

Assignment 1: literature review,  for the 4500-5000 word final report. The system boundary for this project is broad, within the overall domain of sustainability and habitability in the built environment. It involves the critical investigation of a place, or an identified subset of qualities of a place, from a sustainability/habitability perspective, reflecting:

- A consistent theoretical framework which identifies, draws on and references the relevant literature;

- Your observations and other empirical evidence (quantitative and/or qualitative);

- Interaction with and between the users of the place; and

- Your own background and experience.

Your place can be a street, a neighbourhood, a building, a park, etc.

This investigation will inevitably raise questions about the interaction between people and place: not only how the place is used, but why, and its contribution (positive or negative) to sustainability and habitability. In turn this begs the question of whether and how this may be improved, and to what extent more general conclusions can be drawn. 

Assignment 1 involves three stages:

1. Project proposal – you are required to submit a proposal of no more than 500 words (one page Word document) in which you identify your place, why you have selected it, and what aspect(s) you propose to investigate. This will be reviewed, feedback provided and any potential problems highlighted before you begin your substantive research. As this is “formative” assessment, proposals will not be marked, however submission is compulsory. Proposals must be submitted to the course convener as email attachments.

2. Preparation of a literature review and theoretical framework (pdf format, email attachment, approx. 1500 words) relating to your place and your interactions with it.

3. The final report is to submitted as a Turnitin assignment via Moodle

The format of your final report should follow the general structure of a journal article or conference paper, including a clear context (how the project relates to the subject matter of this course), scope, objectives, a critical review of the relevant literature, an outline of the methodology and an exposition of your findings, conclusions and recommendations.

Marks will be awarded based on assessment of the clarity of your argument and explanation, the perceptiveness of your observations and your critical skills in evaluating and drawing on the literature you have selected.

This assignment must be fully referenced using the Harvard (author, date) system. Assignments are to be submitted to the course convener via Turnitin on Moodle. If you have a legitimate reason for a late submission, you must make a formal request for Special Consideration (see http://www.be.unsw.edu.au/student-intranet/academic-policies). Otherwise late submissions will only be accepted at the discretion of the course convener, and marks will be deducted.

In Australia and globally, the challenge of climate change is driving growing interest in the design and construction of high performance buildings which are climate appropriate, energy efficient and generate energy from renewable sources. This studio course provides the opportunity for BE Masters students to work together in teams with colleagues from the Faculty of Engineering on real world, industry-linked projects focused on the integrated design of sustainable, high performance buildings. The studio will be structured around cross-disciplinary collaboration and integration of low energy, passive design strategies from project conception, and will include opportunities for interaction with experienced industry professionals. Lectures in advanced topics of ESD design and evidence based methods and tools, including evaluation and prediction of building thermal, energy and daylighting performance, will complement and inform students' studio work.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SUSD0009 - Environmental Auditing","description":"

Environmental Auditing integrates scientific/engineering principles, technical and environmental aspects of facility operations, knowledge of management systems, regulatory frameworks and audit techniques to evaluate the environmental impacts of an organisation's activities and to manage potential environmental liabilities, risks and hazards. The course provides students with the necessary knowledge to undertake environmental audits of facilities and operations with the objective of minimising environmental risk and improving environmental performance. Topics include environmental risk assessment; material accounting, pollution prevention and cleaner production tools; legislative requirements; environmental indicators and reporting; management systems auditing; and specialist audit types (energy, waste, contaminated sites).  UNSW is Exemplar Global Certified TPECS Provider for the Competency Units EG - AU Management systems auditing and EG - EM Environmental management systems.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"SUSD0010","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"SUSD0010 - Managing the Sustainable Built Environment","description":"

This course focuses on sustainable management of the built environment. It covers strategic asset management from a sustainability/life cycle perspective and integration of sustainability criteria into project procurement, supply chain management, space planning / utilisation and the operational management and maintenance of buildings and facilities. The course introduces and critically examines a range of frameworks and tools to assess, report on and manage energy, water and waste, facilitate stakeholder engagement and address emerging greenhouse and energy compliance requirements. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ddaf5df3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Outline of Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

You must present a one-page outline of your proposed assignment topic for feedback and approval by the Friday of Week 3 (4th October). The topic must be strategic in scope, i.e. it must include a policy / planning / management dimension, and it must address an issue of practical relevance to the sustainable management of the built environment. Note that your one-page outline is NOT marked; the purpose is purely to provide feedback (what is known in the jargon as ‘formative assessment’).

.
The format of your final report should follow the general structure of a research article for a journal or conference, including a clear context (how the project relates to the subject matter of this course), scope, objectives, a critical review of the relevant literature, an outline of the methodology and an exposition of your findings, conclusions and recommendations. Description is necessary, but more so explanation and interpretation – you must establish a theoretical basis for the issues you are investigating. Application of sustainability principles must be informed by a thorough grasp of that which is being applied. The report must be fully referenced using the Harvard (Author, Date) system.

Marks will be awarded based on assessment of your demonstrated understanding of the theoretical and practical basis of the topic, the clarity, depth and consistency of analysis and argument, the validity of your conclusions and your skill in critically evaluating and drawing on the literature pertinent to your subject matter.

Three class seminars relating to three key areas of sustainable BE management are scheduled as per the table below. Teams of five students will be established in Week 2 based on ensuring as far as practicable a spread of different disciplines within each team. You will need to get to know your team early – you will be working with them throughout the course; however, please note that as class numbers are not confirmed until the Census date, there may be some changes to membership of the original teams.

Each team will select a building/facility as their project site. Each team may use the same site to illustrate one, two or all three topic areas or may select a different site for each topic. Each team is required to prepare and deliver a brief (20 minute) slide presentation for each of the three topic areas, which must include a set of prompts/discussion points to help initiate subsequent discussion. Questions and debate will be held over until all groups have presented. In addition, each group must submit a ~2000 word ‘conference paper’ style report. which expands on the material presented in the slides.

The presentations and supplementary report must develop from a theoretical foundation, utilising the relevant literature; be based on empirical evidence (i.e. not arbitrary or speculative); and address salient issues of sustainability as applicable to the particular topic.

Marks will be awarded according to each team’s demonstrated understanding of the subject matter, the
structure and evidence base of the argument and the clarity of exposition (verbal, graphic and written). Each seminar presentation plus accompanying written report is worth 20%, for a total of 60% of marks for this course. Assessment will be conducted as follows: 

:• Each team’s presentation will be assessed by its peers, i.e. each team will provide a group mark and written comments on every other team’s presentation. These marks and comments must be forwarded to the course convener, who will average the scores for each team (10%)

• Each team’s written report will be assessed by the course convener (10%), and each member of each team will be asked to rate his/her own and each other’s contribution to the report (a spreadsheet will be provided). The group mark out of 10 will be multiplied by an averaged contribution mark (from 0 = no contribution to 1 = full contribution) to give an individual mark.

• The combined total of the group presentation mark and the individual report mark will be the student’s individual mark for that seminar (20%)

Each seminar is scheduled at least a week after the lecture which covers the relevant subject matter, to allow time for teams to prepare. As the presentations are run as class seminars, and as teams are required to review each other’s work, attendance at all three Saturday afternoon seminars is required.

contentlets.keywords: sustainable development,facilities management,sustainable built environment,space planning,sustainable procurement,strategic asset management,building life cycle,building maintainability
contentlets.description: This course focuses on sustainable management of the built environment. It covers strategic asset management from a sustainability/life cycle perspective and integration of sustainability criteria into project procurement, supply chain management, space planning / utilisation and the operational management and maintenance of buildings and facilities. The course introduces and critically examines a range of frameworks and tools to assess, report on and manage energy, water and waste, facilitate stakeholder engagement and address emerging greenhouse and energy compliance requirements.
contentlets.title: Managing the Sustainable Built Environment

This course comprises a supervised research project pertinent to the broad domain of sustainable development in the built environment. Students may propose their own research project, or organise a topic in consultation with the course convener. A research topic may extend to areas of interest in closely related disciplines if suitable arrangements can be made for supervision. The objectives, research questions and methodology should be well resolved prior to proceeding with the other aspects of the research. The outcomes should demonstrate advanced understanding of the selected topic and highly developed communication skills. Students should also consider the practical application and potential impact of their research project


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c9517db3db315c50eb6b147a3a961920","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Submission of research report (minor thesis)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"100","description":"

The format is expected to follow the general style of a substantial journal article/monograph or significant professional report. It must establish the context of the investigation, clearly set out the hypothesis or research question(s) and objectives and include:

- A critical review of the relevant literature;

- Justification of the proposed research methodology;

- Effective exposition of the data collection and analysis; and

- Clear description, explanation and interpretation of the findings and conclusions and how these relate back to the original research questions.

Indicative length is 10,000 words, plus supporting photographs, diagrams, tables etc as required to illustrate the argument. The report must be fully referenced using the Harvard (author, date) system.

Design projects focus on the detailed design development of the project proposed in the initial agreed brief, realised through appropriate methods of design representation. Although not specifically a research project, you are expected to research the theoretical aspects of your proposal, articulate the objectives and explore, investigate, analyse and document the context and implications to establish your design proposition.

Project reports or design projects are to be submitted in digital format (for marking) and as hard copy (for archives) directly to the course conveners or via the Student Centre. As the graduate project report is in effect a “minor thesis”, deadlines for submission are arranged individually with the course convener, and will normally be before the end of the Exam period. If you anticipate submitting later than this (e.g. where fieldwork is conducted overseas) you must discuss with the course convener as early as possible.

This course provides foundation knowledge for planning and managing sustainable infrastructure and public services. By infrastructure we mean built facilities and networks – either above or below ground – that support health, safety, and welfare. This is a broad take that traditionally has included publicly- and privately-owned providers of systems such as:


  • Utilities – gas and electricity, water supply and sewerage, waste collection and disposal
  • Public Works – roads and bridges, dams and canals, ports and airports, railways
  • Community Facilities – prisons, schools, parks, recreation, hospitals, libraries
  • Telecommunications - telephony, internet, television, satellites, cable, broadband, etc.

Public services in this context refers to public or social programs designed to benefit a class or classes of citizens, including health care, housing, workfare, education etc.This course prepares students to be proficient in a life-cycle method of infrastructure planning and management, which starts with a needs assessment, and encompasses programming, planning, design, costing, budgeting, financing, operations, maintenance, rehabilitation, replacement/redesign, and evaluation. We will also cover selected infrastructure and service systems, to be selected by the professor in consultation with the students, in order to best meet their interests. These typically include transport, public health, water, sewage treatment, energy, and telecoms. This course provides professionals and researchers with the theory and the tools needed to perform basic infrastructure planning and research. This course is designed to provide a basis for life-long inquiry into infrastructure. It is for students of urban planning, urban design, landscape architecture, architecture, property development, civil and environmental engineering, public health, and public administration.

Students will work individually on an essay topic related to his or her interest, doing research, gathering case studies, data, and illustrations, on a selected infrastructure topic. The essay will be of 2,500 words, not including references. Topics will be discussed and agreed between the student and the lecturer and posted on Moodle by the end of week 2).

The total mark allocated for this assignment is 35% of the final mark. Assessment is based on the individual performance on Assessment Attributes 1,2,3,5, and 6 of Attachment 1 -
Assessment Rubric SUSD0016 for Essays and Reports.

Students will receive feedback on each assessment task in writing via Moodle. Feedback will reflect the level of performance demonstrated in a particular assessment task.

Interim Presentation (Formative) - Each group will submit a progress report in the form of a 5 minute PowerPoint presentation using 4-6 slides on video or voice over PowerPoint via Moodle. Students are encouraged to use this opportunity to test presentation skills of the members of the group. This is not an assessment task. However, each group is expected to do it. The instructor will provide feedback on the submission via
Moodle.

Final Presentation (Summative) - Each group of students will present their project at a gathering of industry partners and academics. Each presentation will be given 10 minutes. Students will also discuss the project with the audience in a question and answer session. A guest panel will assess the quality of each project and select the best Team for the Award of Excellence 2021. The lecturer will mark the presentation.

Total mark allocated for this assignment is 35% of the final mark (20% of marks for individual performance based on Assessment Attributes 1,2,3, and 4 and 15% for group performance based on Assessment Attribute 4 of Attachment 1 - Assessment Rubric SUSD0016 for Essays and Reports).

Students will receive feedback on each assessment task in writing via Moodle. Feedback will reflect the level of performance demonstrated in a particular assessment task.

Prepare a well-argued and well-organized project report of 10,000 words maximum (not including tables, appendices and references), by way of answering the questions raised and discussed, illustrated and with all quotations and concepts fully referenced to the Author, Date and Page from which they are drawn, using the Harvard (Author and Date) System, with illustrations captioned and accurately sources.

Total mark allocated for this assignment is 35% of the final mark (20% of marks for individual performance based on Assessment Attributes 1,2,3, and 4 and 15% for group performance based on Assessment Attribute 4 of Attachment 1 - Assessment Rubric SUSD0016 for Essays and Reports).
